title: Bathurst racer PASSES OUT at wheel after freak accident saw carbon monoxide pumped into his helmet
text:
A racer in the Bathurst 1000 had one of the worst starts to the race possible after toxic gas flooded his helmet, giving him carbon monoxide poisoning.

As the rest of the filed had found their positions on the grid a Holden Team Acroweld Racing car was still on top of Mount Panorama.

However as stewards and others raced out to try and held get the car off the track they discovered it wasn't a mechanical issue, news.com.au reported.

Instead the fan in Brodie Kostecki's helmet had malfunctioned.

Holden Team Acroweld Racing driver Brodie Kostecki (pictured) passed out behind the wheel after his helmet fan fed him carbon monoxide instead of oxygen

As a result of the malfunction Kostecki suffered carbon monoxide poisoning and passed out behind the wheel.

'Cool suit failure has pumped dry ice onto Brodie's head so that's what caused the medical issue. That's remarkable for that to happen,' a Fox Sports commentator said.

The C02 was fed into his helmet from the dry ice in his cool suit system instead of the air that it is supposed to filter through.

As a result of the malfunction Kostecki (left) suffered carbon monoxide poisoning and passed out behind the wheel of the race car

The wild card driver was competing for his family's team at the endurance race.

After a quick medical check Kostecki was cleared to race and he chose to continue on and start the race.

'I'm pretty much back to 100 per cent now,' he told FOX Sports.

'It was a bit scary in the car, I just went to flick my helmet air on and the cool suit wasn't connected up properly inside the (cool) box. I was just breathing in all the dry ice.'
description: Brodie Kostecki had one of the worst starts to the Bathhurst 1000 possible, suffering carbon monoxide poisoning after toxic gas flooded his helmet.
authors: Adam Mccleery For Daily Mail Australia
